conclusion: Solve step by step to find the power of the external force doing work when the rod OC rotates in the magnetic field.
Identify the induced EMF due to motion in magnetic field using Faraday's law.
Understand how the magnetic flux changes as the rod rotates.
The rod OC of length r sweeps out an area as it rotates.
Calculate the area swept per unit time as (1/2) × r² × ω.
Calculate the induced EMF as B × rate of change of area = B × (1/2) × r² × ω = (1/2)Br²ω.
Calculate the current in the circuit using Ohm's law: I = (Br²ω/2)/R = Br²ω/(2R).
Determine the magnetic force on the rod using the formula F = I × L × B × sinθ.
The force acts perpendicular to both the rod and the magnetic field, tangential to the circular path and opposite to the direction of motion.
Calculate the magnetic force as F = I × r × B = (Br²ω/2R) × r × B = B²r³ω/(2R).
For the rod to maintain uniform rotation, an external force must be applied equal and opposite to the magnetic force.
Power is calculated as Force × Velocity.
The tangential velocity at the end of the rod is v = rω.
The average velocity along the rod is v_avg = rω/2.
Calculate the power of the external force as P = F × v_avg = B²r³ω/(2R) × rω/2 = B²r⁴ω²/(4R).
The power of the external force doing work to maintain the uniform rotation of the conductor rod OC is P = B²r⁴ω²/(4R).
This power is required to counteract the magnetic drag force that would otherwise slow down the conductor rod.
